Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial Evaluating Pleth Variability Index in Orthotopic Liver Transplantation

Participants.evidence: Conducted at Inonu University, Turkey, this single-center study involved 25 patients undergoing OLT. Exclusion criteria included cardiac arrhythmias, low left ventricular function, renal dysfunction, valvular heart disease, pulmonary hypertension, or fulminant hepatic failure.

Intervention.evidence: Patients were monitored using the Masimo pulse oximeter and PiCCO 2 system. Fluid loading (10 mL/kg colloid) was administered during the dissection and anhepatic phases.

Objective.evidence: This study assesses the pleth variability index (PVI) as a predictor of fluid responsiveness in OLT, comparing it with other hemodynamic indices from the PiCCO 2 system.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the predictive value of PVI, assessed over two surgical phases.

Number_Analysed.evidence: 14 (56%) and 18 (75%) patients were classified as responders, respectively.

Result_Outcome.evidence: PVI did not significantly predict fluid responsiveness, with an area under the curve (AUC) of 0.56 and 0.55 for the dissection and anhepatic phases, respectively.

Harms.evidence: No adverse events related to the intervention were reported.
